summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan, outlining the government's plan to obtain and review investigative files from the prior Florida investigation into Jeffrey Epstein (2005-2010) for potential disclosure in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. It details the legal framework for disclosure obligations and lists six specific sources of Florida-related files the prosecution team is reviewing. This is a government court filing from October 7, 2020, addressed to Judge Alison J. Nathan. It details the prosecution's planned approach to reviewing materials from prior investigations (specifically the USAO-SDFL Florida investigation and USAO-SDGA's involvement in CVRA civil litigation) for potential Giglio and 3500 material relevant to the Ghislaine Maxwell prosecution. The government asserts these other offices are not part of the current prosecution team but commits to targeted reviews of specific email sets.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The letter is addressed to her, responding to her prior inquiry about the government's plan to review other investigative files.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the prosecution case that is the subject of this filing. The government mentions gathering information regarding her from the USAO-SDGA's CVRA litigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the prior Florida Investigation (2005-2010) for sexual abuse of minors. His case files are being reviewed for potential disclosure in the Maxwell prosecution.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.context: An employee of Jeffrey Epstein who was prosecuted by the FBI Florida Office for obstruction of justice. The prosecution team has received some files from that case.

persons.name: Attorney-1
persons.context: The primary line Assistant U.S. Attorney who worked on the Florida Investigation in the Southern District of Florida. Their emails were gathered by the DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The Acting United States Attorney who submitted this court filing on behalf of the government.

connections.description: Maxwell is charged in a case arising from an investigation into Epstein's activities, indicating an alleged conspiratorial relationship in the abuse of minors.
Rodriguez is identified as an employee of Jeffrey Epstein who was later prosecuted for obstruction of justice related to the Florida investigation.
Attorney-1 was the primary line Assistant U.S. Attorney who worked on the federal Florida Investigation and prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein.
Attorney-1 was the primary prosecutor on the prior Florida investigation into Epstein, which would have involved investigating Maxwell as an associate.
Strauss, as Acting U.S. Attorney, is submitting this legal filing to Judge Nathan, outlining the prosecution's disclosure plans.

events.title: Initial Conference in Maxwell Case
events.description: The Court asked the Government about its plan to ensure timely review of files from other agencies for potential disclosures in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

events.title: Start of Florida Investigation
events.description: The Palm Beach Police Department opened its investigation into Jeffrey Epstein for sexual abuse of minors.

events.title: Referral to FBI
events.description: The Palm Beach Police Department referred its Epstein investigation to the FBI Florida Office.

events.title: Completion of Epstein's Sentence
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein completed his sentence following his guilty plea in the Florida state prosecution.

events.title: SDNY Investigation Opened
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, the FBI New York Office, and the NYPD opened the investigation that led to the charges against Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Electronic Discovery Deadline
events.description: The Government expects to meet this deadline for the completion of electronic discovery productions in the Maxwell case.

events.title: USAO-SDGA Designated for CVRA Litigation
events.description: Attorneys from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Georgia were designated to represent the U.S. in CVRA civil litigation brought by Epstein victims, after the USAO-SDFL was recused.

events.title: Government Files Disclosure Plan
events.description: The government files this document with the court, detailing its planned approach to reviewing materials from prior investigations for disclosure in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

locations: Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The government has produced approximately 328,863 pages of discovery to Ghislaine Maxwell's defense as of October 7, 2020.

The prosecution team is reviewing files from six sources related to the 2005-2010 Florida investigation into Jeffrey Epstein: PBPD, PBSA, FBI Florida Office, USAO-SDFL, DOJ OPR emails, and the Alfredo Rodriguez case.
The government states it has no legal obligation to obtain the Florida files but is doing so 'above and beyond' its disclosure obligations.
The prosecution team had no involvement in the prior Florida investigation, which was conducted by a separate 'Florida Investigative Team'.
The document references an ongoing DOJ Office of Professional Responsibility investigation into the resolution of the prior Florida Investigation.
The government does not believe the prior Florida investigation (USAO-SDFL) and the current Maxwell prosecution have a substantial number of overlapping victims or witnesses.
The government will conduct targeted electronic searches of emails from 'Attorney-1', the primary prosecutor on the Florida case, for names of the defendant, victims, and witnesses.
The government will contact the USAO-SDGA to ask if they gathered any information about Ghislaine Maxwell during their representation in the CVRA civil litigation.
The government explicitly states that none of the other offices (USAO-SDFL, USAO-SDGA) played any role in investigating, charging, or presenting the current Maxwell case to the grand jury.
The filing is a formal commitment to a 'thorough, careful, and comprehensive approach' to disclosure obligations, specifically regarding Giglio and 3500 material.
